hints_html:
The slope-point form equation of a line with slope \(m\) passing through \((x_0, y_0)\) is \(y - y_0 = m(x - x_0)\). How can we use the information in the question to find an equation for the tangent line?

By definition, the slope of the tangent line to \(\displaystyle f\) at \(\displaystyle (x_0, f(x_0))\) is \(\displaystyle f'(x_0)\).

hints_raw:
The ''slope-point'' form equation of a line with slope <math>m</math> passing through <math>(x_0, y_0)</math> is <math>y - y_0 = m(x - x_0)</math>. How can we use the information in the question to find an equation for the tangent line?
By definition, the slope of the tangent line to <math>\displaystyle f</math> at <math>\displaystyle (x_0, f(x_0))</math> is <math>\displaystyle f'(x_0)</math>.
question: A 04
sols_html:
Noting that \(f(x_1) = 0\), we solve for \(x_1\) using the equation of the tangent line to \(f\) at \((x_0, f(x_0))\):

\[\begin{aligned} y - y_0 &= m(x - x_0) \\ f(x_1) - f(x_0) &= f'(x_0)(x_1 - x_0) \\ 0 - f(x_0) &= f'(x_0)(x_1 - x_0) \\ x_1 &= { \color{blue} x_0 - \frac{f(x_0)}{f'(x_0)} }\end{aligned}\]

which is answer \({\color{blue}\text{(E)}}\).
statement_html:
Shown in the figure below is a function and its tangent line at \(x = x_0\).

The tangent line intersects the \(x\) axis at the point \(x = x_1\). The coordinate of the point \(x_1\) is

(a) \(x_1 = x_0 + \frac{f(x_0)}{f'(x_0)}\)

(b) \(\displaystyle x_1 = x_0 - f'(x_0)(x-x_0)\)

(c) \(x_1 = x_0 - \frac{f'(x_1)}{f(x_1)}\)

(d) \(x_1 = x_0 + \frac{f'(x_1)}{f(x_1)}\)

(e) \(x_1 = x_0 - \frac{f(x_0)}{f'(x_0)}\)
